title.value: Probabilistic Mobility Load Balancing for Multi-band 5G and Beyond Networks
title.justification: Title of the paper in context
title.quote: Probabilistic Mobility Load Balancing for Multi-band 5G and Beyond Networks

extractions.description: The paper addresses the challenge of load balancing in multi-band 5G and beyond networks, proposing a probabilistic mobility load balancing (PMLB) algorithm. The algorithm models load balancing as a multi-objective stochastic optimization problem, aiming to distribute user equipment (UE) traffic evenly across bands while minimizing handovers. The approach leverages linear programming and event-based operations to enhance network performance, as demonstrated through simulation results.

type.justification: The paper involves simulations to demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed algorithm in enhancing network performance.
type.quote: Simulation results show that the proposed algorithm enhances the network’s performance and outperforms traditional load balancing approaches in terms of throughput and interruption time.

primary_research_field.justification: The research focuses on load balancing algorithms within the scope of 5G networks, which involves advanced computational techniques like stochastic optimization and machine learning.
primary_research_field.quote: We have modeled the UE-band assignment problem as an integer multi-objective stochastic optimization problem.

sub_research_fields.justification: The proposed work and related works within the paper utilize reinforcement learning methods for mobility load balancing in networks.
sub_research_fields.quote: Apart from rule-based methods, numerous learning-based methods were proposed and were shown to be superior to rule-based methods.

name.justification: Referenced as part of past methods employed for reinforcement learning in mobility load balancing.
name.quote: The authors proposed a hierarchical RL algorithm to control both MLB CIOs for active UEs, and the cell reselection parameters for inactive UEs to mitigate overloading cells, which resulted in much better performance.
